content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the Act. It aims to improve coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to consolidate export promotion activities, clarify roles of committee members, include State agency representatives, and report on improvements to Export.gov. The Promotion Coordinating Committee will report on improvements to Export.gov as a single window for export information and developing a single window for information about export control compliance. This is part of the Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 to facilitate export opportunities for small businesses. Sec. 201-206 outline various initiatives to promote exporting, including a small business export matchmaking pilot program and an inter-agency task force on export financing. Title I focuses on improving coordination of export promotion programs, consolidating duplicative activities, and providing information on trade missions and trade fairs. In amending Section 2312(b) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988, changes include identifying opportunities to consolidate or co-locate offices of agencies involved in export financing activities and enhancing the use of electronic databases for resource allocation. The Secretary of Commerce shall provide a detailed listing of current and future Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities to ensure better delivery of services to United States businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make information on trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency in the TPCC, describing their goals and objectives for measuring and reporting. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency in the TPCC, including recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States related to coordination. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency in the TPCC, including recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States related to coordination. Additionally, the amendment involves replacing "United States National Tourism Organization" with "United States Travel Association" in paragraph (8). The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. Additionally, reports to Congress regarding the activities of the TPCC are required. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report should include details on the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, and the implementation of sections 303 and 304 of the FREEDOM Support Act. The TPCC chairperson must submit an annual report to Congress by March 30, detailing the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, funding for export promotion activities, and interagency working groups on energy. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce is required to prepare and submit reports to congressional committees. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce must submit an annual report to Congress by March 30, assessing the TPCC's performance in carrying out its duties and implementing the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies' inspectors general to prepare the annual report on TPCC's performance and strategic plan implementation. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other federal agencies' inspectors general and appropriate congressional committees regarding the TPCC. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with various congressional committees including the Committee on Finance, Committee on Foreign Relations, Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship, Committee on Appropriations, Committee on Energy and Commerce, Committee on Financial Services, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee on Small Business, and Committee on Ways and Means. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for exporting information. Export.gov is designated as a comprehensive resource for exporting information and a single website for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The entities specified include small business concerns that are exporters and the President's Export Council, State agencies responsible for export promotion or financing. Small business concerns that are exporters and entities like the President's Export Council, State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations, and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to appropriate congressional committees within 180 days, evaluating the benefits of a single website for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
(1) "Administration" and "Administrator" refer to the Small Business Administration and its Administrator.
(2) "Region of the Administration" is defined in section 3(u) of the Small Business Act.
(3) "Small business concern" is defined in section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. SEC. 202 amends the Small Business Act to include promoting exporting through outreach events in each state. SEC. 203 establishes a Small Business Export Matchmaking Pilot Program. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers. At least one event will be held annually in each region, and events may be coordinated with outreach events. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers, as required by the Small Business Act. The authority for this program will terminate on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
